comments:
In some cases the DestroyEObjectCommand causes NPE and prevents elements from being deleted. If that happens to an element in a resource then it seems that none of its elements can be deleted.

Here is the stack trace:

java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.common.core.command.AbstractCommand.execute(AbstractCommand.java:130)
	at org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.emf.core.util.EObjectUtil.destroy(EObjectUtil.java:226)
	at org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.emf.commands.core.commands.DestroyEObjectCommand.doExecuteWithResult(DestroyEObjectCommand.java:90)
	at org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.emf.commands.core.command.AbstractTransactionalCommand.doExecute(AbstractTransactionalCommand.java:245)
	at org.eclipse.emf.workspace.AbstractEMFOperation.execute(AbstractEMFOperation.java:127)
	at org.eclipse.emf.workspace.CompositeEMFOperation.doExecute(CompositeEMFOperation.java:212)
	at org.eclipse.emf.workspace.AbstractEMFOperation.execute(AbstractEMFOperation.java:127)
	...    ...   ...

Further investigation into the client scenario shows that the client was trying to execute the UnexecutableCommand instance, which returns null from #doExecuteWithResult().

This defect will address both problems:
+ make the AbstractCommand#execute() more robust and check for a null command result before trying to get its status

+ UnexecutableCommand throws an UnsupportedOperationException when it is asked to execute, rather than returning null
